text:
Hundreds of Yemeni Bodega Owners Rally Against Refugee Ban in Brooklyn By Ben Fractenberg | February 2, 2017 4:33pm View Full Caption DNAinfo/Ben Fractenberg 
DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN — Hundreds of Yemeni bodega owners and workers rallied against President Donald Trump's refugee ban in front of Brooklyn Borough Hall Thursday afternoon. 
The protesters shut down their bodegas and delis across the city from noon to 8 p.m. while they spoke out against Trump's executive order limiting entry for refugees and immigrants from seven predominantly Muslim countries, including Yemen. 
"We want to be free like anyone else," said Amin Awadh, 25, who works at a bodega in Queens. "We're all Americans." Bodega workers protest Trump's refugee ban in downtown Brooklyn. @DNAinfoNY #BodegaStrike pic.twitter.com/TKmw5Io3zH — Ben Fractenberg (@fractenberg) February 2, 2017 
Hundreds of people were packed into the square behind the hall, while others filled the staircase leading up to it. Protesters waved Yemeni and American flags, chanting "U.S.A." and "No ban, no wall, U.S.A. for all." 
The ban caused havoc at airports across the country on Saturday as hundreds of people flying into the U.S. were detained at places like John F. Kennedy Airport . 
Up to 6,000 bodegas are owned by Yemeni immigrants across the five boroughs, rally organizers said. 
Store owners started posting signs in solidarity after shutting down Thursday afternoon.
